rounds.response:
Here you have 7♠ 8♣ with absolutely nothing but an open-ended straight draw (need a 6 or a 9 for a straight). Your effective stack is ~980 and villain’s effective stack is ~960, so you are both deep. The pot is 60 and villain just put out a 20-chip cbet. You have ~20 % equity if all your outs are clean (which is optimistic because some 6s / 9s might make villain a higher straight or boat), and you’d need ~25 % to call profitably.  

Folding is the sensible tight play, but at 20 chips (1/3-pot) you can occasionally float and see if you turn equity or can steal later. That said, you have deeper stacks and limited blind pressure; playing this draw passively is high-variance.  

The EV-smart choice is to cut the losses and look for better spots:

This is an extremely strong hand that is beating everything except a flopped straight or higher set, both of which are extremely unlikely. With the pot at 320 and effective stacks of 800 left behind, I need to bet for value and protection.

I should bet large enough to extract value from any king, straight-draw spades, or even a smaller set, while still keeping all worse hands in. Something around the size of the pot (320) or slightly below seems ideal to keep opponent committed if they pair the king or hold any made hand.

[ Bet 260 ]
